verse: While Apollos was in Corinth, Paul traveled through the interior regions [the mountainous northern route through the interior of Phrygia; 18:23] to Ephesus [a major city in western Asia Minor; 18:23]. There he found some ·followers [disciples]
and asked them, “Did you receive the Holy Spirit ·when [or after] you believed?”
So he asked, “·What kind of baptism did you have [Into what were you baptized]?”

Paul said, “John’s baptism was a baptism of ·changed hearts and lives [repentance; in preparation for the Messiah]. He told people to believe in the one who would come after him, and that one is Jesus.”
When they heard this, they were baptized ·in [or into] the name of the Lord Jesus.

Then Paul ·laid [placed] his hands on them [a ritual of blessing and/or conferring of authority], and the Holy Spirit came upon them. They began speaking ·different languages [or in tongues; ecstatic utterance] and prophesying.
There were about twelve people in this group.

Paul went into the synagogue and spoke out ·boldly [confidently; fearlessly] for three months. He ·talked [reasoned; argued] with the people and persuaded them ·to accept the things he said about [concerning] the kingdom of God.

But some of them became ·stubborn [hardened]. They refused to believe and ·said evil things about [slandered; cursed] ·the Way of Jesus [the Way; another name for the Christian movement; 9:2; 18:25; 22:4] before ·all the people [the crowd]. So Paul left them, and taking the ·followers [disciples] with him, he went to the ·school [lecture hall] of a man named Tyrannus. There Paul ·talked [discussed; reasoned; debated] with people every day
for two years. Because of his work, ·everyone who lived in [the whole population of] the province of Asia, both Jews and Greeks, heard the word of the Lord.
God ·used Paul to do [through the hands of Paul did] some ·very special [extraordinary] miracles.

Some people took ·handkerchiefs [face cloths] and ·clothes [work aprons; or hand towels] ·that Paul had used [that had touched Paul; from his skin] and put them on the sick. When they did this, ·the sick were healed [the diseases left them] and evil spirits ·left [came out of] them.

But some ·people also were traveling around and making evil spirits go out of people [traveling/itinerant Jewish exorcists…]. They tried to ·use [invoke; name] the name of the Lord Jesus to force the evil spirits out. They would say, “By the same Jesus that Paul ·talks about [preaches; proclaims], I ·order [command; adjure] you to come out!”
Seven sons of Sceva, a ·leading [Jewish chief] priest, were doing this.
But one time ·an [the] evil spirit said to them, “I know Jesus, and I ·know about [recognize] Paul, but who are you?”

Then the man who had the evil spirit ·jumped on [leaped on; attacked] them. Because he ·was so much stronger than all of them [violently overpowered them], they ran away from the house naked and ·hurt [wounded].
All the people [who lived] in Ephesus—Jews and Greeks—learned about this and were filled with fear and ·gave great honor to [praised/magnified the name of] the Lord Jesus.
Many of ·the believers [those who now believed] began to confess openly and ·tell all the evil things they had done [disclose their (evil/magical) practices].

·Some [or A significant number] of them who had ·used magic [practiced sorcery/witchcraft] brought their magic ·books [or scrolls] and burned them before everyone. Those books were worth about fifty thousand silver coins [probably drachmas, each worth a day’s wages].
·So in a powerful way [In this way; Thus] the word of the Lord kept spreading and ·growing [or grew strong; prevailed].

After these things [had been fulfilled/accomplished], Paul decided [in his spirit; or in the Spirit] to go to Jerusalem, planning to go through Macedonia [northern Greece] and Achaia [southern Greece] and then on to Jerusalem. He said, “After I have been ·to Jerusalem [there], I must also ·visit [see] Rome.”
Paul sent Timothy and Erastus, two of his ·helpers [assistants], ahead to Macedonia, but he himself stayed in [the province of] Asia for a while.
And during [or about; at] that time, there was ·some serious trouble [no small disturbance] in Ephesus about ·the Way of Jesus [the Way; another name for the Christian movement; 9:2; 18:25; 22:4].

A man named Demetrius, who worked with silver, made little silver ·models that looked like the temple [shrines; probably reliefs depicting the goddess in her temple] of the goddess Artemis [Greek goddess of fertility, worshiped particularly in Ephesus]. ·Those who did this work [The artisans/craftsmen] made much money [had no little business].

·Demetrius [He] had a meeting with them and ·some others [workers] who did ·the same kind of work [or similar trades]. He told them, “Men, you know that ·we make a lot of money [our wealth/livelihood comes] from this business.

But ·look at [you have seen and heard] what this man Paul is doing. He has ·convinced [persuaded] and ·turned away [or led astray] many people, not only in Ephesus, but in almost all of [the province of] Asia! He says the gods made by human hands are not ·real [gods (at all); Is. 44:9–20; 46:1–7; 1 Cor. 8:4–6].

There is a danger that our business will ·lose its good name [be discredited], but there is also another danger: People will begin to think that the temple of the great goddess Artemis is not important, and the goddess herself, whom everyone in [the province of] Asia and the whole world worships, will ·lose [be deposed of/stripped of] her majesty [magnificence; greatness].
When the others heard this, they became ·very angry [enraged; furious] and shouted, “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”

The whole city ·became confused [was filled with confusion; was in an uproar]. The people grabbed Gaius and Aristarchus [20:4; 27:2; Col. 4:10; Philem. 24], who were from Macedonia and were traveling with Paul, and ·ran [rushed together] to the theater.
Paul wanted to ·go in and talk to the crowd [appear before the assembly], but the ·followers [disciples] did not let him.

Also, some ·leaders of Asia [provincial authorities; of the Asiarchs; a group of wealthy political leaders who had religious functions] who were friends of Paul sent him a message, ·begging [urging; encouraging] him not to ·go [venture; take the risk of going] into the theater.
Some people were shouting one thing, and some were shouting another. The ·meeting [assembly] was completely confused; most of them did not know why they had come together.

The Jews ·pushed forward [put in front] a man named Alexander, and some of them [either the crowd or the Jews] ·told him to explain [or gave him advice on what to say; or assumed he was responsible for the trouble]. Alexander ·waved [gestured with] his hand [for silence] so he could ·explain things to [or make a defense before] the ·people [crowd].

But when they ·saw [recognized] that Alexander was a Jew [Jews opposed idol worship, so the crowd was suspicious of him], they all shouted ·the same thing [in unison; with one voice] for two hours: “Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!”

Then the city clerk [the head of the assembly and the senior local official] quieted [calmed down] the crowd. He said, “·People of Ephesus [Men, Ephesians], ·everyone knows [who does not know…?] that Ephesus is the city that ·keeps [guards] the temple of the great goddess Artemis and her ·holy stone [or image; or statue] that fell from heaven [probably a meteorite that resembled the many-breasted image of Artemis].
Since no one can say this is not true, you should ·be quiet [keep calm]. ·Stop and think before you do anything [Do nothing reckless/rash].
You brought these men here, but they have not ·said anything evil against [blasphemed] our goddess or ·stolen anything from [or committed sacrilege against] her temple.

If Demetrius and ·those who work [the artisans/craftmen] with him have a ·charge [complaint; grievance; word] against anyone, ·they should go to the courts and judges [the courts are open/in session and there are proconsuls] where they can ·argue with [or bring charges against] each other.
If there is something else you want to talk about, it ·can [or must] be decided at the ·regular town meeting of the people [legal assembly; which met three times a month].

I say this because [we are in danger that] some people might see this trouble today and ·say that we are [accuse us of; charge us with] rioting. We could not explain this, because there is no real reason for this ·meeting [or uproar; commotion].”
After the city clerk said these things, he ·told the people to go home [dismissed the assembly].
